childMarkdownRemark.html:
Ingredients:

  • 1 small bitter melon (ampalaya), seeds removed and sliced
  • 1 medium-sized eggplant, sliced
  • 1 small squash (kalabasa), peeled and cubed
  • 1 cup long beans (sitaw), cut into 2-inch pieces
  • 2 medium-sized tomatoes, quartered
  • 1 medium-sized onion, chopped
  • 4 cloves garlic, minced
  • 2 tablespoons cooking oil
  • 1 cup water
  • 2 tablespoons shrimp paste (bagoong)
  • Salt, to taste

Instructions:

  1. In a large pan or wok, heat the cooking oil over medium heat.

  2. Saut√© the garlic until fragrant and golden brown. Add the onions and cook until they become translucent.

  3. Add the tomatoes and cook until they soften and release their juices.

  4. Add the shrimp paste (bagoong) to the pan and stir it into the mixture. Let it cook for a minute to enhance the flavors.

  5. Add the bitter melon, eggplant, squash, and long beans to the pan. Stir to combine and coat the vegetables with the shrimp paste mixture.

  6. Pour in the water and bring it to a simmer. Cover the pan and let it cook for about 10-15 minutes, or until the vegetables are tender.

  7. Season with salt to taste. Be mindful of the saltiness of the shrimp paste, so adjust accordingly.

  8. Remove from heat and transfer the Pinakbet to a serving dish.

  9. Serve hot with steamed rice. Pinakbet is often enjoyed alongside grilled or fried fish or meat dishes.

Pinakbet is a hearty and flavorful dish that showcases the vibrant and diverse flavors of Filipino vegetables. Enjoy!
